ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We also had occasional online discussion boards.
There was live lecture only and then various different types of assignments like presentations, quizzes, etc.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It expanded my vocabulary, and greatly improved writing/reading comprehension skills. Learned more about the differences in spoken Chinese and formal written Chinese.
I learned more about how to speak formally in Chinese.
My Chinese vocabulary expanded a lot in this class.
Further learned grammatical structures and Chinese vocabulary, and learned how to write more formally.
I learned to improve my speaking and listening skills for Mandarin, in addition to learning more about Chinese culture.
I learned how to speak chinese, critically think, and learned about chinese culture and heritage.
I continued improving on Chinese grammar structures, conversational skills, and essay-writing ability through this course.
I learned about certain grammatical structures that were more formal and greatly improved my speaking ability and general vocabulary.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Small seminar-style class was very nice, and made the class feel engaging. Class slides were very relevant to homework assignments and never felt rushed. Overall strengths: small class, very friendly and engaging teacher who would leave feedback on almost every assignment, welcoming environment. Weaknesses: rarely, assignment guidelines and due dates were unclear, and had to be addressed via email or class announcements

I really liked the community that we built as a class. It was very nice to be in a community with other Chinese heritage speakers. I liked how the classes were not too lecture-like. However, I believe that sometimes there was not enough time in class to finish everything we wanted to cover, and class often went over time.
You learn a lot of new words and your vocab expands a lot, but because the class moves so fast, I didn't feel like my writing or reading skill improved by that much.

Strengths - the pace of the course and the textbook
Improve - more in class grammar and speaking practice. The inherent nature of zoom made it difficult to do speaking practice, but I really enjoyed doing typing practices to learn new grammar structures.

Strengths: assignments were all designed so that we had an easier time in a remote setting and the professor was clear on the instructions and grading standard. 

Weaknesses: sometimes there were too many different assignments to get through for one day, but then again the professor is lenient if you contact her about an extension
There was a lot of good in-class discussion. Engaging activities and a wide variety of projects.
This class was sooooo amazing. Best class I've taken so far, Professor Xu is amazing!

Strengths: Xu Laoshi is wonderful and does a great job trying to make the class interesting for everyone and genuinely cares about the progress and troubles of each student. She really creates such a friendly environment for the whole class, and even though the class took place virtually this semester, I still felt like I had connected and gotten to know both her and my classmates.
Strengths: Xu Laoshi, textbook, feedback on essays was very detailed. Weaknesses: grades are kind of confusing

This course is good at introducing new Chinese vocabulary at a good pace, and allowing students to practice using those words. I don't think my skills of handwriting Chinese characters from memory have improved much, but given the virtual format of classes this semester it was likely not very possible to do that. I also think that more lessons about Chinese culture and history would be appreciated.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Probably the most engaging Zoom class I had this semester. Clas was engaging as everyone would turn their videos on. The in class quizzes were easy and fun, and were done via private message with the teacher. Exams were all online on Canvas, and taken during class time, and the format was nice.

I was able to virtually engage as the instructor asked the class many questions in class and selected students to answer questions randomly, which maintained homogenous participation among the whole class. I think the main thing that could be improved was the online discussion boards because often times students just replied once to a discussion thread and never engaged with it again. I think instead of starting so many discussion threads, we should all engage in once main thread and all build our comments off of eachother.

The typing grammar practice was very helpful. I believe that it was hard to do speaking practice because of Zoom and class stayed generally quiet. I wish there was a way to speak more in class. I also wish we had more handwriting practice.

I thought that making the students take the test while being on a zoom call was inconvenient, not to mention Zoom itself can take up bandwidth and slow internet down for those who already have slow internet. I felt self-conscious while being on a zoom call while taking the test. However, other than that, I felt that the course did a great job at adapting, especially for a language class that usually relies so much on participation.
In-person discussions were engaging and fun.
Communication via email was very effective, also it was cool that the powerpoints we created could be shared via share screen.
Iw wish there were opportunities for the class to meet in person socially distanced.

Her enthusiasm made the class fun to be in. She also did a great job translating class activities into collaborative online activities that would let us work together with our peers. Nothing to improve.
Zoom format worked well when the teacher was presenting material, but didn't allow much opportunity in the way of student-to-student interaction, which is to be expected I guess.

Engagement during classes was very good for the virtual formatXu Laoshi would make sure each student spoke at least once during each class. The final project, a dubbing project over a film, was also somewhat unintuitive in design but the end products were all very entertaining and fun to watch.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Definitely, if you speak Chinese at home but aren't very good on the reading/writing front. The class is very approachable, and starts with very small steps to build a solid foundation of vocab. You can't go wrong with any teacher as the Chinese department faculty are all amazing and friendly.
I would recommend this course to another student. It is a great place to build a community with other Chinese heritage speakers as well as simply practice and maintain my Chinese fluency.
Take it if you genuinely want to improve your Chinese skill. Be prepared to spend a lot of time on it if you want to get the most out of this class
Yes. I learned a lot in this course and I found it to be very helpful as a heritage speaker to consistently practice writing and listening.

Yes, this is very much a course where you get out what you put in. If you are willing to take the time to practice your Chinese and learn about the culture, you can improve a lot and meet a lot of great people.
Yes, a great L5 course.
Yes, Xu Laoshi is very kind, and also the class is very involved and conducive to improving your Chinese abilities.
YESSSS SO AMAZING

For anyone continuing from CHNS 142, this course was not significantly more difficult nor rigorous. In fact, since CHNS 152 is a 1.0 credit course rather than a 1.5 credit course, those coming from CHNS 142 and lower will find that the workload is much lower.
I would definitely recommend this course to any heritage Chinese students looking to improve their Chinese skills in all areas.
Definitely take this class over 132 if you're on the fence. It will greatly improve your reading/writing. Overall, the class was really fun and not that many major assignments.
Yes, this course is a great way to get back into studying Chinese in a classroom setting.
